I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Nepal  for  the  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation  (SASEC)  Mugling–Pokhara 
Highway Improvement Phase 1 Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance 
(TA) for Enhancing Road Safety, Disaster Risk Reduction, and Project Implementation Capacity, 
and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.  The project will improve the capacity, reliability, and safety of road links between Pokhara, 
Nepal’s second-largest city, and Mugling, a central junction of the strategic road network (SRN) 
that further links to Kathmandu, the administrative and economic capital; and Bharatpur, Nepal’s 
fourth-largest city and a gateway to the East–West Highway and international markets. The 
project will finance the first phase of upgrading Mugling–Pokhara Highway, and will (i) rehabilitate 
and widen to four lanes the 81-kilometer (km) section between Abukhaireni and Pokhara, and (ii) 
increase awareness and strengthen the capacity of the Department of Roads (DOR) in road safety 
and disaster risk reduction. A second phase, covering the 8 km section between Mugling and 
Abukhaireni, will be considered as a subsequent project because of engineering constraints.1 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Country context. Nepal is landlocked and bordered to the north by the People’s Republic 
of China, and to the south, east, and west by India. Consequently, Nepal relies heavily on its 
direct neighbors for international trade, mainly India which traded 65% of Nepal’s imports and 
exports in fiscal year (FY) 2019. Economic growth improved to 7.3% per year on average during 
FY2017–FY2019, compared with an annual average of 3.3% during FY2014–FY2016. However, 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  largely  depends  on  exogenous  factors,  such  as 
remittances, which accounted for 25.4% of GDP in FY2019; and rainfall, as agriculture accounted 
for 27% of GDP in FY2019.2 Nepal’s economy suffers from a lack of competitiveness and is 
particularly hampered by its deficient infrastructure network and the resulting high operating costs 
and travel times, which (i) constrain the development of competitive export supply chains,3 (ii) 
hinder the exploitation of its natural resources and tourism potential,4 and (iii) impede regional 
integration and trade with indirect neighbors.5 
 
                                                
1  The 8 km, two-lane section between Mugling and Abukhaireni cannot be widened to four lanes because of steep 
slopes and the presence of a hydropower plant. A second project phase will thus include (i) the construction of a 
greenfield, two-lane alignment on the opposite side of the valley between Mugling and Abukhaireni; and (ii) the 
rehabilitation and improvement of the two-lane section. Feasibility and detailed design studies are ongoing for phase 
2, which is under consideration for financing in 2021.

Kathmandu. Exports decreased by 3.6% annually and in real terms from FY2009 to FY2019. Sustained by foreign

FY2019. 
4  World Travel & Tourism Council. 2018. Travel & Tourism Economic Impact 2017. London. The contribution of tourism

government’s ambition of reaching 2 million tourists by 2020. 
5  Excluding India, trade with other South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) members accounts for

2 
4.  Transport sector. Roads are the predominant mode of transport for more than 90% of 
goods and passengers, although road density remains low at 47 km of road per 100 square 
kilometers of land area, and 2.5 km per 1,000 people.6 The SRN totals 12,494 km, 51% of which 
is paved, and is developed and maintained by the DOR in the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure 
and Transport (MOPIT). The number of registered vehicles increased from 0.7 million in FY2009 
to 3.2 million in FY2018, and motorcycles accounted for 79.6% of sales. Vehicle registrations are 
expected to quadruple by 2029, highlighting the need to increase capacity. The high traffic fatality 
rate of 15.9 fatalities per 100,000 people also mandates road safety improvements, notably by 
strengthening road designs.7 The SRN maintenance budget increased by 10.0% annually and in 
real terms during FY2013–FY2020; however, the average budget utilization of 81% requires 
improvements in asset management and planning practices. International and domestic air travel 
increased by 7.2% and 2.0% annually during 2011–2018, but capacity constraints at Kathmandu 
airport inhibit growth.8 
 
5.  Sector road map. The transport sector is guided by the National Transport Policy, 2002; 
the Priority Investment Plan, 2007–2016; and MOPIT’s 5-year strategic plan.9 The road sector 
strategy of the government’s Fourteenth Plan, 2017–2019 aims to (i) expand the SRN to improve 
interprovincial and national connectivity; (ii) promote economic growth through higher regional 
integration; (iii) reconstruct roads damaged by the April 2015 earthquake; (iv) provide greater 
access to social services and markets; (v) improve road safety and road maintenance; and (vi) 
support the development of the agriculture, industry, energy, and tourism sectors.10 
 
6.  Subregional cooperation. The government strategy is aligned with subregional policies, 
notably SASEC’s objectives to facilitate trade, enhance accessibility to national and transnational 
markets, and improve connectivity through the development of multimodal transport systems.11 
The improvement of the East–West Highway—Nepal’s main domestic and international trade 
corridor—and of its feeder roads is recognized by the government and development partners as 
a priority to implement the strategies. The project is part of a comprehensive set of interventions 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the government, and the World Bank to improve Nepal’s 
major highways.12 The project is consistent with the objectives of ADB’s country partnership 
strategy for Nepal, 2013–2017 to enhance global–local connectivity, and is included in ADB’s 
country operations business plan, 2019–2021; and in SASEC’s operational plan, 2016–2025.13 
 
7.  Regional context. Pokhara is the capital of the Gandaki Province and has a population 
of about 450,000 people in 2019. It is a major economic and social hub for its hinterland, although 
Pokhara’s location at the foot of the Himalayas impedes connectivity and restricts access to 
markets, jobs, and social opportunities. The sinuous 200 km journey to Kathmandu takes over 5 
hours by road. There are no railway or waterway connections, and its domestic airport handled

up from 22% in 2001).14 
 
8.  Project design. The project road is the primary access link of Pokhara to Kathmandu and 
is a major feeder road of two SASEC corridors linking Kathmandu to Dhaka (Bangladesh) and 
Kolkata (India) through Mugling and the East–West Highway. It is a two-lane carriageway that 
handles about 7,400 vehicles per day, including 14% of goods vehicles and up to 55% of 
motorcycles in urban areas. Traffic is forecast to increase to 13,000 vehicles per day by 2040, 
and the rising number of motorcycles creates significant road safety risks, notably as (i) the road 
winds through the mid-hill region of Nepal and its geometry can be improved, (ii) slow-moving 
vehicles and pedestrians are not segregated in urban areas, and (iii) the pavement is in poor 
condition.15 The road will be widened to four lanes to cater to increasing demand, and design 
standards will feature enhanced geometry, pavement, structure, drainage, safety, and intelligent 
traffic system features to improve sustainability, safety awareness, and safety compliance. The 
road will be median divided, and service lanes in urban areas will improve safety, particularly for 
women and children, who are more likely to walk, ride a bicycle, or use public transport than men. 
 
9.  Project  benefits.  The  project  will  directly  support  economic  growth  by  (i)  lowering 
transport costs and reducing logistics constraints; (ii) improving accessibility to domestic markets, 
jobs, and social services; (iii) enhancing national connectivity between Pokhara and Kathmandu; 
and (iv) facilitating access to international markets through Bharatpur and India. Consequently, 
the project is expected to (i) promote the development of the private sector and competitive export 
supply chains in Pokhara and its hinterland, (ii) increase domestic and international trade, (iii) 
improve regional integration, and (iv) leverage Pokhara’s tourism potential. The project will also 
increase connectivity and urban road safety for the major settlements located between Mugling 
and  Pokhara,  and  strengthen  disaster  resilience  by  installing  a  landslide  monitoring  and 
management system and replacing the structurally weak Madi bridge. 
 
10.  ADB’s interventions and lessons learned. ADB is a leading partner for the development 
of the SRN and has financed five projects from 2010 to 2018 to improve about 1,212 km of road, 
totaling $690.8 million.16 The project design incorporates lessons from previous projects, notably 
on (i) project preparation: a preparatory facility financed the detailed design to minimize initial 
implementation delays, and the project is procurement ready;17 (ii) procurement: three large works 
packages are expected to attract experienced international contractors and improve the quality of 
works; (iii) material availability: a consulting services package will be carried out to assess 
nationwide  material  availability  and  quality;  (iv)  disaster  risk  resilience:  climate  adaptation 
measures and the attached TA will strengthen landslide monitoring and management capacity; 
and  (v)  asset  sustainability:  performance-based  maintenance  contracts  will  ensure  funding

11.  Alignment with Strategy 2030. The project will contribute to achieving the following 
operational priorities:18 
 
(i)  Accelerating progress in gender equality. The project will (a) promote women’s 
economic empowerment by reducing time poverty and improving access to social, 
health, job, and market opportunities; (b) target women in awareness campaigns 
on road safety, disaster risk reduction, HIV/AIDS, sexual harassment, abuse, 
exploitation, and human trafficking; and (c) target vulnerable and women-headed 
affected households in livelihood improvement programs. 
(ii)  Tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and 
enhancing environmental sustainability. Significant disaster risk reduction and 
climate adaptation measures, totaling 15.6% of civil works costs, will strengthen 
disaster risk resilience. The attached TA will also develop a landslide monitoring 
and management system to mitigate environmental sustainability risks. 
(iii)  Strengthening governance and institutional capacity. The project will improve 
(a) service delivery through the civil works contracts, which were designed to 
improve works quality, improve the completion timeline, and promote private sector 
participation  in  the  road  maintenance  during  operation;  and  (b)  institutional 
capacity in traffic management, procurement, and contract management. 
(iv)  Fostering  regional  cooperation  and  integration.  The  project  will  enhance 
connectivity and competitiveness to promote regional trade, tourism, and value 
chains; and is aligned with SASEC’s strategy and operations plan (footnote 11). 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
12.  The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) transport connectivity within Nepal 
and  with  neighboring  countries  improved  (footnote  10),  and  (ii)  physical  connectivity  and 
multimodal linkages for land-based transport along major trade routes enhanced (footnote 11). 
The project will have the following outcome: efficiency and safety of the road transport system 
improved.19 
 
13.  Output 1: Road network upgraded and maintained. The loan will finance the upgrading 
of about 81 km of road between Abukhaireni and Pokhara from two to four lanes, and feature (i) 
improved safety, including crash barriers in hilly areas, and service lanes for pedestrians, bicycles, 
and motorcycle users in urban areas; (ii) intelligent transport system equipment, such as traffic 
lights and warning systems; and (iii) enhanced sustainability, with a 5-year performance-based 
maintenance period. The project road includes nine major bridges, including two for which a 
separate civil works contract package is provided, in addition to 26 minor bridges. 
 
14.  Output 2: Awareness of communities and capacity of government staff on road 
safety, disaster risk reduction, and project implementation improved. The loan will finance 
a landslide monitoring and management system, and awareness campaigns on road safety, 
                                                
18  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

disaster risk reduction, human trafficking, HIV/AIDS, sexual harassment, abuse, and exploitation. 
The attached TA will support institutional capacity improvement of MOPIT and DOR in landslide 
management, intelligent traffic monitoring systems, procurement, and contract management. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
15.  ADB’s value addition includes close coordination with DOR to strengthen road designs 
and incorporate improved disaster risk reduction, climate change adaptation, environmental, road 
safety, and maintenance planning practices. The attached TA will strengthen DOR’s capacity in 
disaster risk reduction, road safety, and procurement and contract management. Intelligent traffic 
systems equipment will improve road safety, and performance-based maintenance contracts will 
strengthen road asset management and maintenance capacity. 
 
16.  Development coordination. The project complements and strengthens best practices 
introduced in previous projects in safety, maintenance, procurement, and gender mainstreaming. 
It is closely aligned with SASEC’s strategy, which aims to promote trade along specific identified 
cross-border corridors, and aligns with interventions of development partners, particularly (i) the 
World Bank, which financed the upgrading of Mugling–Narayanghat Road, completed in 2018, 
and is expected to finance Mugling–Naubise Road; and (ii) the Japan International Cooperation 
Agency, which is financing the Naubise–Nagdhunga tunnel. ADB is expected to continue to 
finance strategic roads, including phase 2 from Mugling to Abukhaireni (footnote 1), and other 
sections of the East–West Highway that are part of the SASEC corridor, in 2021–2022. In addition 
to closely cooperating on infrastructure development planning, ADB and the World Bank align 
their institutional development strategies, particularly on road safety and maintenance.

maintenance costs; half of project management costs; and about 17.6% of all other project costs.

III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
21.  The transaction TA for Enhancing Road Safety, Disaster Risk Reduction, and Project 
Implementation Capacity will complement infrastructure improvements by supporting capacity 
building and institutional strengthening of MOPIT and DOR. The TA will support three outputs: 
 
(i)  intelligent traffic management and information system for road safety developed, 
including the design of a safety-oriented plan to incorporate intelligent transport 
systems and road safety technologies in the project road; 
(ii)  landslide  monitoring  and  management  system  for  disaster  risk  reduction 
developed,  including  the  identification  of  landslide-sensitive  areas  and  the 
preparation of a risk monitoring and reduction plan; and 
(iii)  procurement and contract management capacity enhanced, including training 
courses on procurement of works, contract management, and dispute resolution 
under the International Federation of Consulting Engineers. 
 
22.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6).22 The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff, data, maps, and other in-kind contributions. Equipment 
packages under the loan will support the implementation of the intelligent traffic management and 
information system, and of the landslide monitoring and management system. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
23.  DOR prepared the engineering designs of the project road in accordance with the Asian 
Highway  Class  1  standard,  and  aimed  to  improve  road  safety  and  geometry,  avoid  land 
acquisition, and minimize social and environmental impacts. The project road will be widened 
from two to four lanes, and the completed road will have a design speed of 80 km per hour, dual 
carriageways  separated  by  a  3-meter  median,  3-meter  shoulders  on both  sides,  and  new 
pavements. The project will integrate safe and socially inclusive design features, such as 41 km 
of footpaths, 20 km of service lanes segregating slow-moving vehicles, 46 disabled-friendly 
pedestrian crossings, 46 sheltered bus stops, and reflective lane markers.  
 
24.  The project road is in the subtropical climate zone with high rainfall and heat hazard risks, 
high rainfall-induced landslide risks in sections of the road traversing steep terrain, medium 
earthquake risk, and very low river flooding risks. The main climate risks in the project area are 
temperatures increasing by 1.2°C–1.7°C during 2019–2050, rainfall levels increasing by 15%–
                                                
22 Attached  Technical  Assistance  Report:  Enhancing  Road  Safety,  Disaster  Risk  Reduction,  and  Project 
Implementation Capacity (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
20% during 2019–2050, and extreme rainfall increasing in frequency. To address these risks, 
engineering designs of the road and bridges have integrated climate adaptation measures, 
including slope protection works, increased road embankment and bridge heights, and increased 
cross and side drainage capacity. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
25.  Economic viability. The economic evaluation of the project followed ADB guidelines and 
compared life cycle economic costs and benefits in with- and without-project scenarios, using a 
9.0% discount rate and the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) as decision criteria.23 The 
highway development model 4 was used to estimate road agency and road user costs based on 
input data on traffic; road geometry; pavement condition; and maintenance, improvement, and 
operating costs. The analysis considered the project costs of the entire Mugling–Pokhara corridor, 
including phase 2 of the project. Project benefits include savings associated with vehicle operating 
costs, travel time, and road accidents (unquantified). The EIRR of the project is estimated at 
13.9%. Sensitivity analysis demonstrated the robustness of the economic viability of the project 
under adverse changes in costs and benefits, with an EIRR of 11.9% under the most sensitive 
scenario involving a 10% increase in capital costs and 10% decrease in benefits. 
 
26.  Financial viability. The project is not revenue generating, and cost recovery will not be 
sought. The Roads Board of Nepal funds maintenance from allocations of the Ministry of Finance 
and from toll revenues. The annual SRN maintenance budget increased from NRs2.7 billion in 
FY2013 to NRs8.0 billion in FY2020 in nominal terms, or an annual growth rate of 16.7% in 
nominal terms and 10.0% in real terms. The project’s average annual incremental recurrent costs 
are estimated at 0.75% of the maintenance budget, and it is thus reasonable to expect that DOR’s 
budget allocation will be able to meet the project’s incremental maintenance costs, particularly 
considering that the road is a major highway and trading corridor of Nepal.24 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
27.  The FY2020 budget, which doubled the allocation for road maintenance, also introduced 
a tax of NRe1.0 per liter of fuel and diesel to be channeled toward road maintenance. Despite the 
increasing commitment of the government and the minimal impact of the project on DOR’s 
maintenance budget, the historical underfunding of road maintenance still represents a risk to the 
project’s sustainability, as the maintenance budget could be channeled toward other roads 
requiring more urgent maintenance. Consequently, the project design incorporated the following 
measures to mitigate the risk of funding availability and strengthen the project’s sustainability: 
(i)  Civil  works  contracts  include  a  1-year  defect  liability  period  and  a  5-year 
performance-based maintenance period under the responsibility of the contractors 
after construction. This will strengthen works quality by the contractor, promote 
private sector participation in the maintenance of the project road  under the 
supervision  of  DOR,  and  guarantee  the  availability  of  budget  and  physical 
resources in the initial phase of operation. 
(ii)  The project design includes adaptation measures estimated at 15.6% of capital 
costs, compared with about 5.0% for most road projects, which represent a 
strengthening of technical specifications against assessed environmental and 
climate risks. The attached TA will also support institutional capacity improvements 
in landslide management and disaster risk reduction. 
                                                
23 ADB. 2017. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila. 
24  Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
D.  Governance 
 
28.  Institutional capacity. The 2015 Constitution of Nepal, which introduced three tiers of 
government, entrusted the development and management of the national highway network to the 
federal government, under MOPIT and DOR. The Project Directorate (ADB) of DOR, which 
handles project management for ADB’s strategic road sector projects, has good technical capacity 
and significant experience implementing ADB projects. Its project director reports to DOR’s 
director general, who in turn reports to the MOPIT’s secretary. The capacity of DOR will be 
strengthened through consulting services contracts for (i) construction supervision, which include 
training in design, contract management, and quality assurance; (ii) an independent design 
checking for third-party review and approval of bridge designs; and (iii) a raw material survey to 
assess raw material availability, quantity, and quality for construction projects across Nepal. 
 
29.  Financial  management.  The  assessed  pre-mitigation  financial  management  risk  is 
moderate  mainly  because  DOR  has  an  established  record  in  implementing  ADB-financed 
projects, and adequate financial management capacity in accounting, disbursement procedures, 
and reporting. All transactions are recorded by government accounting systems, reflected in 
government  accounts,  and  subjected  to  statutory  audit  by  the  comptroller.  The  project 
management  unit  maintains  separate  books  of  accounts  following  government  accounting 
standards, under the cash basis of accounting; and prepares annual project financial statements, 
which  are  audited  by  Nepal’s  Office  of  the  Auditor  General.  The  financial  management 
assessment identified the following risks: (i) increasing financial management requirements, 
particularly with the increasing project pipeline, coupled with frequent project staff turnover; (ii) 
lack of comprehensive financial information in periodic project progress reports; and (iii) weak 
internal audit. The main risk mitigation actions include (i) assigning additional financial staff to 
project field offices, (ii) ensuring proper training in ADB systems and procedures, and (iii) including 
additional financial information in the quarterly progress reports as agreed with ADB. 
 
30.  Procurement. Procurement and consultant recruitment will follow the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers 
(2017, as amended from time to time). The amended Public Procurement Act (2017) and Public 
Procurement Regulations (2017) of Nepal are generally acceptable to ADB and encompass best 
international procurement practices. While Nepal’s procurement risk rating is substantial, DOR 
has significant experience with ADB’s procurement requirements, and the sector and project 
procurement risks are moderate. Engagement of all consulting firms will use the quality- and cost-
based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. Advance actions for the recruitment of 
construction supervision consultants started in August 2019, and invitation for bids for the two 
road packages were published in September 2019. 
 
31.  Integrity due diligence was conducted.25 No significant integrity risks were identified. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government and MOPIT. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are 
described in the PAM. 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
32.  Poverty. The direct area of influence of the project includes 456,273 residents living in 10 
municipalities crossed by the project road, in the districts of Kaski and Tanahu. About 11.8% of 
                                                
25 ADB. 2003. Enhancing the Asian Development Bank’s Role in Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism. Manila.

10 
residents live below the national poverty line, below the national average of 18.7%. The major 
income sources are remittances (22%), agriculture (21%), trade (20%), and services (12%). 
Access to sanitation (99%) and piped water (95%) is high. The project is expected to improve 
access to economic opportunities and social services, reduce intraregional disparities, promote 
the development of trade and tourism, and encourage the creation of competitive export jobs and 
services; the project is also expected to create about 1.65 million person-days of skilled and 
unskilled employment during construction. 
 
33.  Gender. The project is categorized some gender elements. A poverty and social analysis 
assessed the socioeconomic characteristics of 1,297 households—including 322 households 
headed by women—representing 6,828 people, 50% of them women and girls. Overall, women 
were supportive of the positive impact that the project will deliver, including expected increased 
accessibility to education and health facilities, reduced travel time, and expanded access to 
agricultural products and job markets. The gender benefits of the project also include (i) a safer 
urban environment, with infrastructure features friendly to elderly people, women, children, and 
people with disabilities; (ii) livelihood improvement programs prioritizing  vulnerable affected 
households and affected households headed by women; (iii) ensured participation of women in 
awareness programs on road safety, disaster risk reduction, HIV/AIDS, and human trafficking; 
and (iv) ensured participation of female MOPIT and DOR staff on capacity building activities. 
Gender, social development, livelihood improvement, and road safety awareness experts will be 
hired to support the gender activities of the project. 
 
34.  HIV/AIDS and human trafficking. HIV prevalence in Nepal is low,  at 0.2% of the 
population aged 15–49.26 About 39 HIV incidences were recorded in the districts affected by the 
project, while about 50 nongovernment organizations work in HIV prevention. Human trafficking 
in Nepal remains prevalent, with an estimated 5,957 cases of abducted persons in FY2016 (80% 
involving women and children, primarily for forced labor and sexual exploitation). While the project 
will facilitate movements of people and require a significant labor force, it will widen an existing 
corridor and is not expected to contribute to a significant increase in HIV/AIDS and human 
trafficking. The project will recruit a nongovernment organization to conduct an HIV/AIDS and 
human trafficking awareness campaign along the road corridor. The contractors will also conduct 
HIV/AIDS awareness sessions and provide voluntary testing and guidance to their workforce. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
35.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.27 
 
36.  Environment (category B). The project road will be rehabilitated and widened to four 
lanes in the existing right-of-way, and the road is not located in or near any environmentally 
sensitive area. The environmental impacts of the project are not expected to be significant and 
irreversible, and will be mainly restricted to the construction stage. Anticipated impacts involve 
landslide  and  erosion,  dust,  noise,  exhaust,  construction  and  domestic  waste,  water 
contamination, occupational health and safety, siltation, traffic congestion during construction, 
and air pollution and road safety during operation. An initial environmental examination has been 
prepared for the project and was disclosed on the ADB website in July 2019; it includes an 
environmental management plan providing mandatory mitigation measures to be implemented by 
contractors. Concerns voiced by affected persons and stakeholders during project preparation 
                                                
26 Government of Nepal, Ministry of Health and Education. 2014. Country Progress Report on HIV/AIDS. Kathmandu. 
27 ADB. Safeguard Categories.

11 
were incorporated in the design, and a grievance redress mechanism will alleviate concerns 
during  implementation.  About  6,694  trees  will  need  to  be  removed  and  a  compensatory 
afforestation program will be implemented, with a ratio of 25 saplings planted for each felled tree. 
 
37.  Involuntary resettlement (category A). The project will require private land acquisition 
of 1.28 hectares, where the existing alignment is insufficient to meet the requirements of the 
project design, mainly at intersections and bridges. The project will affect 143 private land parcels 
belonging to 122 households, with parcels mostly comprising small strips of uncultivated (1.21 
ha) and cultivated (0.07 ha) land on either side of the existing road. There is no major impact on 
the income of affected households arising from the loss of land. 
 
38.  The project will affect 810 households (3,985 persons) and 767 private structures along 
the right-of-way; 85% of affected households are non-titled, and only 4% are below the poverty 
line. A resettlement plan was prepared for the project road and is disclosed on the ADB website.28 
The entitlement matrix provided under the resettlement plan includes mitigation measures and 
resettlement  assistance  commensurate  with the  project  impacts;  incorporates  lessons from 
previous projects; and provides compensation at replacement cost for land, structures and trees, 
shifting  and  reconstruction  assistance,  loss  of  income,  and  livelihood  measures.  Public 
consultations  were  undertaken  from  2016  to  May  2019  and  will  continue  as  the  plan  is 
implemented. An adequate grievance redress mechanism is in place at the project level, in 
addition to the provisions for redress under the Land Acquisition Act of Nepal (1977). Livelihood 
measures will particularly target vulnerable households and households headed by women. 
Institutional arrangements and capacity to implement the plan are adequate. 
 
39.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project road does not cross traditional customary 
or tribal lands. More than half of affected households belong to various ethnic groups recognized 
by the government (mainly Dalit, Gurung, Magar, and Newar); however, they share the same 
income-generating  activities  and  access  to  services  and  opportunities  as  other  affected 
households. The social impact assessment also indicates that households from these groups tend 
to have a higher socioeconomic status than others, are well integrated, will not be impacted 
differently, and will benefit equally from the project. The project will also not impact the dignity, 
human rights, livelihood systems, or culture of ethnic groups; or affect the territories or the natural 
and  cultural  resources  that  they  own,  use,  or  occupy.  Cultural  aspects  were  considered 
particularly during public consultations, information disclosure, livelihood improvement measures, 
and the grievance redress mechanism. 
 
40.  Implementation. DOR is experienced and has adequate institutional capacity regarding 
ADB’s procedures and requirements, and the Project Directorate (ADB) will implement the 
environmental safeguards and resettlement plan. Resettlement and environment specialists will 
support the Project Directorate (ADB) in guiding and reviewing the implementation of safeguard 
plans and documentation. Environmental, gender, and social experts from the construction 
supervision consultants will assist DOR with the implementation and monitoring of safeguard and 
gender activities. Contractors will be required to have environmental, health, and safety officers 
to ensure the environmental management plan is properly implemented. An external monitor will 
provide a third-party review of the resettlement plan. The government will finance and implement 
environmental and resettlement activities. Detailed implementation arrangements are in the PAM. 
 
                                                
28 Resettlement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

12 
G.  Summary of Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 
 
41.  Significant risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.29 The integrated benefits and impacts 
are expected to outweigh the costs.

V.  ASSURANCES 
 
42.  The government and MOPIT have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement 
as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
43.  The government and MOPIT have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
44.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$195,000,000 to Nepal for the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Mugling–Pokhara 
Highway Improvement Phase 1 Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional 
terms, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period and 1.5% per 
year thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms 
and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President

metadata.Subject: The project will improve the capacity, reliability, and safety of road links between Pokhara, Nepal’s second-largest city, and Mugling, a central junction of the strategic road network (SRN) that further links to Kathmandu, the administrative and economic capital; and Bharatpur, Nepal’s fourth-largest city and a gateway to the East–West Highway and international markets.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated October 2019 is provided for the ADB project 52097-002 in Nepal.
